skill.name: working-with-spreadsheets
skill.description:
Creates and edits Excel spreadsheets with formulas, formatting, and financial modeling standards.
Use when working with .xlsx files, financial models, data analysis, or formula-heavy spreadsheets.
Covers formula recalculation, color coding standards, and common pitfalls.
skill.summary:

skill.author: Asmayaseen

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation and prompt-based skill. Contains only markdown documentation and a local verification script that validates the skill structure. No network access, no filesystem access beyond its own directory, no command execution, and no environment variable access.

content.value_statement: Users struggle to create professional Excel spreadsheets with correct formulas and financial modeling standards. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for working with openpyxl and pandas to build maintainable, error-free spreadsheets with proper color coding, number formatting, and formula validation.
actual_capabilities: Create new Excel workbooks with openpyxl and pandas
Apply financial model color coding standards (blue, black, green, red)
Format cells with currency, percentage, and number formats
Edit existing spreadsheets including inserting and deleting rows and columns
Validate formulas and check for common errors like #REF! and #DIV/0!
Create cross-sheet references and external links
limitations: Does not execute Excel calculations - formulas are written but not calculated by openpyxl
Does not support .xls format (legacy Excel files)
Does not provide chart or graph creation functionality
Does not perform data visualization within spreadsheets

use_cases.title: Build financial models
use_cases.description: Create maintainable financial models with proper color coding, formulas instead of hardcoded values, and professional formatting.

use_cases.title: Export analysis to Excel
use_cases.description: Read Excel files with pandas for analysis and write results back to spreadsheets with proper formatting and formulas.

use_cases.title: Automate spreadsheet tasks
use_cases.description: Automate repetitive spreadsheet tasks like formatting, adding formulas, and validating existing spreadsheets for errors.

prompt_templates.title: Create simple spreadsheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Excel file named sales_report.xlsx with columns for Product, Q1 Sales, Q2 Sales, and Total. Use formulas for calculations and format currency cells appropriately.

prompt_templates.title: Apply color coding
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a financial model following color coding standards. Blue for input cells, black for formulas, green for cross-sheet references, and yellow background for key assumptions.

prompt_templates.title: Validate formulas
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a verification script that checks an Excel file for formula errors including #REF!, #DIV/0!, #VALUE!, and #NAME? errors. Report the count and locations of each error type.

prompt_templates.title: Complex financial model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a multi-sheet financial model with assumptions sheet, income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement. Use cross-sheet references and ensure all formulas calculate correctly.

output_examples.input: Create a spreadsheet for monthly expense tracking with categories, amounts, and totals
output: Created expense_tracker.xlsx with columns: Category, Description, Amount, Date
Applied blue font color to input cells (Category, Description, Amount, Date)
Used black font color for formula cells (row totals and grand total)
Formatted currency cells with thousands separator: $#,##0
Sheet ready for monthly expense entries

best_practices: Always use Excel formulas instead of calculating values in Python to maintain spreadsheet integrity
Follow financial model color coding: blue for inputs, black for formulas, green for cross-sheet links
Run verification scripts to catch formula errors before sharing spreadsheets
Use data_only=True mode in openpyxl only when you want calculated values and accept losing formulas on save
anti_patterns: Hardcoding calculated values instead of using Excel formulas
Saving files with data_only=True mode which removes formulas on save
Mixing input cells and formula cells without visual distinction
Using column numbers beyond 52 (like 64 = BL) without proper mapping

faq.question: Does this skill support .xls files?
faq.answer: No, this skill only supports .xlsx files through openpyxl. Use xlrd or pyxlsb for legacy .xls format files.

faq.question: How do I recalculate formulas after creating a spreadsheet?
faq.answer: Open the spreadsheet in LibreOffice or Excel to recalculate. The verification script can identify formula errors but cannot execute calculations.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with Google Sheets?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Excel .xlsx files. For Google Sheets, use the Google Sheets API with gspread library instead.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only processes data within the AI session. No data is sent to external servers or stored beyond the generated spreadsheet files.

faq.question: Why do formulas show as text instead of calculating?
faq.answer: openpyxl writes formulas but does not calculate them. Open the file in Excel or LibreOffice to see calculated values.

faq.question: How is this different from manual Excel work?
faq.answer: This skill enables programmatic spreadsheet creation and editing, making it repeatable, version-controllable, and automatable compared to manual Excel work.
